param.label: Specify input alignment file in PHYLIP, FASTA, NEXUS, CLUSTAL or MSF format.
Specify sequence type as either of DNA, AA, BIN, MORPH, CODON or NT2AA for DNA, amino-acid, binary, morphological, codon or DNA-to-AA-translated sequences
param.help:
This is only necessary if IQ-TREE did not detect the sequence type correctly. Note that -st CODON is always necessary when using codon models (otherwise, IQ-TREE applies DNA models) and you also need to specify a genetic code like this if differed from the standard genetic code.
-st NT2AA tells IQ-TREE to translate protein-coding DNA into AA sequences and then subsequent analysis will work on the AA sequences. You can also use a genetic code like -st NT2AA5 for the Invertebrate Mitochondrial Code (see genetic code table)."

param.label: Specify a file containing starting tree for tree search
Like -t but fixing user tree
param.help: That means, no tree search is performed and IQ-TREE computes the log-likelihood of the fixed user tree.

param.label: Specify a random number seed to reproduce a previous run
Keep identical sequences in the alignment
param.help: By default: IQ-TREE will remove them during the analysis and add them in the end.

param.label: Turn on safe numerical mode to avoid numerical underflow for large data sets with many sequences (typically in the order of thousands)
param.help: This mode is automatically turned on when having more than 2000 sequences.

param.label: Specify the number of quartets to be randomly drawn
param.help: If you specify -lmap ALL, all unique quartets will be drawn, instead.

param.label: Specify a NEXUS file containing taxon clusters (see below for example) for quartet mapping analysis.
Write quartet log-likelihoods into .lmap.quartetlh file (typically not needed).
Skip subsequent tree search, useful when you only want to assess the phylogenetic information of the alignment.

section.name: modelling_parameters
section.title: Modelling Parameters
section.section: TESTONLY Perform standard model selection like jModelTest (for DNA) and ProtTest (for protein). Moreover, IQ-TREE also works for codon, binary and morphogical data. TEST Like -m TESTONLY but immediately followed by tree reconstruction using the best-fit model found. So this performs both model selection and tree inference within a single run. TESTNEWONLY Perform an extended model selection that additionally includes FreeRate model compared with -m TESTONLY. Recommended as replacement for -m TESTONLY. Note that LG4X is a FreeRate model, but by default is not included because it is also a protein mixture model. To include it, use -madd option (see table below). TESTNEW Like -m MF but immediately followed by tree reconstruction using the best-fit model found. TESTMERGEONLY Select best-fit partitioning scheme like PartitionFinder. TESTMERGE Like -m TESTMERGEONLY but immediately followed by tree reconstruction using the best partitioning scheme found. TESTNEWMERGEONLY Like -m TESTMERGEONLY but additionally includes FreeRate model. TESTNEWMERGE Like -m MF+MERGE but immediately followed by tree reconstruction using the best partitioning scheme found. TESTONLY TEST TESTNEWONLY TESTNEW TESTMERGEONLY TESTMERGE TESTNEWMERGEONLY TESTNEWMERGE nuclear mitochondrial chloroplast viral AIC AICc BIC

param.label: Turn on optimizing weights of mixture models
param.help: Note that for models like LG+C20+F+G this mode is automatically turned on, but not for LG+C20+G.

param.label: Specify the Gamma shape parameter (default: estimate)
Perform the median approximation for Gamma rate heterogeneity instead of the default mean approximation (Yang, 1994)
Specify the proportion of invariable sites (default: estimate)
Perform more thorough estimation for +I+G model parameters
Write per-site rates to .rate file
Specify partition file for edge-equal partition model
param.help: That means, all partitions share the same set of branch lengths (like -q option of RAxML).

param.label: Like -q but allowing partitions to have different evolutionary speeds (edge-proportional partition model).
Specify partition file for edge-unlinked partition model
param.help: That means, each partition has its own set of branch lengths (like -M option of RAxML). This is the most parameter-rich partition model to accomodate heterotachy.

param.label: Specify a guide tree (in Newick format) to infer site frequency profiles.
Specify a site frequency file, e.g
param.help: the .sitefreq file obtained from -ft run. This will save memory used for the first phase of the analysis.

param.label: Switch to posterior maximum mode for obtaining site-specific profiles
param.help: Default: posterior mean.

param.label: Specify number of initial parsimony trees
Specify number of top initial parsimony trees to optimize with ML nearest neighbor interchange (NNI) search to initialize the candidate set
Specify number of trees in the candidate set to maintain during ML tree search
Specify number of unsuccessful iterations to stop
Specify number of iterations to stop
param.help: This option overrides -nstop criterion.

param.label: Specify SPR radius for the initial parsimony tree search
Specify perturbation strength (between 0 and 1) for randomized NNI
Turn on more thorough and slower NNI search
Avoid computing ML pairwise distances and BIONJ tree.
Specify a topological constraint tree file in NEWICK format
param.help: The constraint tree can be a multifurcating tree and need not to include all taxa.

param.label: Specify number of replicates (>=1000) to perform SH-like approximate likelihood ratio test (SH-aLRT) (Guindon et al., 2010)
param.help: If number of replicates is set to 0 (-alrt 0), then the parametric aLRT test (Anisimova and Gascuel 2006) is performed, instead of SH-aLRT.

param.label: Perform approximate Bayes test (Anisimova et al., 2011).
Specify number of replicates (>=1000) to perform fast local bootstrap probability method (Adachi and Hasegawa, 1996).
Specify a file containing a set of trees
param.help: IQ-TREE will compute the log-likelihoods of all trees.

param.label: Specify the number of RELL (Kishino et al., 1990) replicates (>=1000) to perform several tree topology tests for all trees passed via -z
param.help: The tests include bootstrap proportion (BP), KH test (Kishino and Hasegawa, 1989), SH test (Shimodaira and Hasegawa, 1999) and expected likelihood weights (ELW) (Strimmer and Rambaut, 2002).

param.label: Used together with -zb to additionally perform the weighted-KH and weighted-SH tests.
Used together with -zb to additionally perform the approximately unbiased (AU) test (Shimodaira, 2002)
param.help: Note that you have to specify the number of replicates for the AU test via -zb.

param.label: Only estimate model parameters on an initial parsimony tree and ignore a full tree search to save time.
Specify a fixed user tree to estimate model parameters
param.help: Thus it behaves like -n 0 but uses a user-defined tree instead of parsimony tree.

param.label: Specify a file containing a set of trees.
Compute consensus tree of the trees passed via -t
param.help: Resulting consensus tree is written to .contree file.

param.label: Compute consensus network of the trees passed via -t
param.help: Resulting consensus network is written to .nex file.

param.label: Specify a minimum threshold (between 0 and 1) to keep branches in the consensus tree
Specify a burn-in, which is the number of beginning trees passed via -t to discard before consensus construction
param.help: This is useful e.g. when summarizing trees from MrBayes analysis.

param.label: Specify an input “target” tree file
param.help: That means, support values are first extracted from the trees passed via -t, and then mapped onto the target tree. Resulting tree with assigned support values is written to .suptree file. This option is useful to map and compare support values from different approaches onto a single tree.

param.label: Specify name of a node in -sup target tree
param.help: The corresponding node of .suptree will then be assigned with IDs of trees where this node appears. Special option -suptag ALL will assign such IDs for all nodes of the target tree.

param.label: Specify a file containing a set of trees.
Specify a second set of trees
param.help: IQ-TREE computes all pairwise RF distances between two tree sets passed via -t and -rf

Compute RF distances between adjacent trees passed via -t

param.help: IQ-TREE will create a random tree under Yule-Harding model with specified number of taxa

Like -r, but a random caterpillar tree is created.
Like -r, but a random balanced tree is created.

Specify three numbers: minimum, mean and maximum branch lengths of the random tree
Specify number of bootstrap replicates (>=1000).

Specify maximum number of iterations to stop

Specify a small epsilon to break tie in RELL evaluation for bootstrap trees
Specify the resampling strategies for partitioned analysis
param.help: By default, IQ-TREE resamples alignment sites within partitions. With -bspec GENE IQ-TREE will resample partitions. With -bspec GENESITE IQ-TREE will resample partitions and then resample sites within resampled partitions (Gadagkar et al., 2005).

param.label: Perform an additional step to further optimize UFBoot trees by nearest neighbor interchange (NNI) based directly on bootstrap alignments
param.help: This option is recommended in the presence of severe model violations. It increases computing time by 2-fold but reduces the risk of overestimating branch supports due to severe model violations. Introduced in IQ-TREE 1.6.

param.label: Specify number of bootstrap replicates (recommended >=100)
param.help: This will perform both bootstrap and analysis on original alignment and provide a consensus tree.

param.label: Like -b but omit analysis on original alignment.
Like -b but only perform bootstrap analysis (no analysis on original alignment and no consensus tree).
Specify a list of comma-separated integer numbers
param.help: The number of entries should be equal to the number of states in the model (e.g. 4 for DNA and 20 for protein). IQ-TREE will then add a number of constant sites accordingly. For example, -fconst 10,20,15,40 will add 10 constant sites of all A, 20 constant sites of all C, 15 constant sites of all G and 40 constant sites of all T into the alignment.
